title: 110_s365
content: The "H-Prize Act of 2007" establishes prize authority under the Department of Energy, defining key terms such as administering entity, Department, and Secretary. The Secretary will award cash prizes to advance hydrogen energy technologies through competitive programs, encouraging broad participation from individuals, universities, and businesses. Prize competitions will be advertised widely, including in the Federal Register. The Secretary will award cash prizes to advance hydrogen energy technologies through competitive programs. The notice in the Federal Register will include details such as the subject, duration, eligibility requirements, registration process, prize amount, and award criteria. An agreement with a private, nonprofit entity will be made to administer the competitions, including tasks like advertising, fundraising, and developing winner selection criteria. The Secretary will award cash prizes for prize competitions based on goals provided, determining prize amounts, selecting judges, and protecting participants' intellectual property. Prizes will be funded by Federal appropriated funds and funds from the administering entity. No special consideration will be given to private entities in exchange for funds. The Secretary may announce prize competitions under this Act, with funds needed for prizes to be appropriated or committed in writing by the administering entity. The authority for prize competitions will end on September 30, 2018. SEC. 4. PRIZE CATEGORIES. The Secretary will establish prizes for advancements in hydrogen-related technologies, prototypes of hydrogen-powered vehicles, and transformational changes in hydrogen production and distribution technologies. The Secretary will establish biennial awards for significant advances in hydrogen-related technologies, with prizes not exceeding $1,000,000 each. If less than $4,000,000 is available, the Secretary may adjust the prizes or omit subcategories. The Secretary will hold a prize competition biennially for prototypes, with prizes not exceeding $4,000,000 each. Additionally, a prize competition for transformational technologies will be announced soon after the enactment of the Act. The prize offered under this paragraph shall be a lump sum of $10,000,000 to the winner, with additional funding matching the private funding raised by the winner for hydrogen technology. The match will be provided for 3 years or until the full prize amount is paid out. The winner can choose to have the match amount paid to another entity continuing the technology development. The Secretary will announce the rules for receiving the match in the required notice. The prize will be awarded when a registered participant meets the established criteria. The prize award under this paragraph is limited to $10,000,000 in Federal funds, with an additional $40,000,000 sought for matching awards. Criteria for the prize will be established in consultation with various entities, and judges will be appointed for each competition. The Secretary will assemble a panel of judges from outside the Department, including the private sector, to select winners based on established criteria. Judges must not have personal or financial interests in participants or familial relationships with them. SEC. 5 of the Act outlines eligibility criteria for winning a prize, including compliance with requirements, being a US entity or citizen, and not being a Federal entity or employee. SEC. 6 of the Act states that the Federal Government will not claim intellectual property rights from participants in prize competitions authorized by the Act. It allows for negotiation of licenses for intellectual property developed during these competitions. The Secretary may require registered participants to waive claims for any injury, death, damage, or loss arising from participation in a competition under this Act, except for willful misconduct. Liability insurance is required for registered participants. Liability insurance or financial responsibility is required for registered participants in competitions under this Act. The Federal Government must be named as an additional insured under the insurance policy, and participants must agree to indemnify the Government against third party claims related to competition activities. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2017 includes $20,000,000 for awards in section 4(a)(1), $20,000,000 for awards in section 4(a)(2), and $10,000,000 for the award in section 4(a)(3). Additionally, $2,000,000 is authorized for administrative costs each year. Funds for prize awards under this Act can be carried over and transferred. The funds authorized in this Act can be used until 10 fiscal years after the original appropriation, and cannot be used in violation of the Anti-Deficiency Act. SEC. 9. NONSUBSTITUTION. The programs created under this Act are not a substitute for Federal research and development programs.
